title: Professional Development and Ethics I
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Professional issues, ethical principles and practice are introduced and illustrated by the use of case studies and discussions. Students are also introduced to applying the range of principles to ethical practice and decision making.

title: Professional Development and Ethics II
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: Speech therapy is more than just clinical skills and practice. A competent speech therapist should understand the range of professional issues related to speech-language pathology which may contribute and influence their clinical practice, decision making as well as the profession. Entry-level professional issues, advanced ethical practice and clinical decision making as well as transition to workforce issues are discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to understand the concept of professional development and ethics

title: Evidence Based Appraisal for Speech Language Pathology I
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course covers basic methodology in research design in the behavioral sciences and basic statistical tools and techniques for analyzing experimental data. Knowledge and procedures of critical appraisal in the practice of evidence-based health care will be introduced. Approaches to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of clinical programmes are covered.

title: Test Development & Assessment Approaches
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: Assessment is a major component in the study of speech-language pathology. This course will introduce key assessment approaches including norm-referenced, criterion-referenced and dynamic tests. Students will learn about the characteristics of each type of assessment, the meaningful interpretation of test scores as well as the potential application in communication disorders in culturally and linguistically diverse populations. Students will learn major procedures in test development from item construction to data collection to evaluation. Critical concepts of psychometric properties of test evaluation will be covered.

title: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech, Language and Hearing
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology and BA Bimodal Bilingual Studies
description: An introduction to the anatomical and physiological aspects to the auditory, respiratory, laryngeal, and swallowing systems is provided. There will be lectures, in-class activities and laboratory sessions. Students will be exposed to anatomy and physiology software, 3D models and the 3D Anatomage Table (life-sized visualization system) to enhance learning.

title: Fluency Disorders
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course discusses the nature, symptoms, and prevalence of stuttering disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with fluency disorders.

title: Voice and Laryngeal Disorders
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course discusses the nature, symptoms and prevalence of voice and laryngeal disorders. Students will be provided with the basic knowledge on assessing, counselling, and treating persons with voice and laryngeal disorders.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the nature, symptoms and prevalence of voice and laryngeal disorders2. Assess and manage persons with voice and laryngeal disorders.

title: Acquired Neurogenic Communication Disorders
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course gives an overview of the human's nervous system in terms of its structure and function. The primary focus is on the nervous system in the reception and expression of speech and language. Speech and language disorders resulting from cardiovascular and cerebrovascular damage due to trauma, disease and adventitious central nervous system (CNS) events will be included. Evaluation and management of the related language, speech and cognitive disorders will be covered.

title: Multimodal Communication
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: The course introduces the methodologies and technologies used to promote the development of communication skills in individuals with various kinds of communication disorders including cerebral palsy and multiple disabilities. The impact of augmentative communication in social interaction, personal growth, educational & vocational opportunities, as well as other aspects of human interaction will be discussed.

title: Language Disorders from Infancy to Adolescence I
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: The course focuses on language disorders from infancy to adolescence. The course will expose students to assessment methods and techniques encompassing the three main language domains of form, content and use with direct hands-on experience with relevant and specified standardised and non-standardised assessments. The range of treatment approaches will be covered with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches and practice. Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play.

title: Speech Sound Disorders
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course covers children's acquisition of speech, articulatory foundations of speech, transcription of speech and classification and causes of speech sound disorders. The course will introduce students to the different types of speech sound disorders, differentiating between those involving phonology (e.g. phonological impairment) and those related to motor speech (e.g. articulation impairment). Students will also be exposed to person-centred functional goals directly addressing the WHO ICF (International Classification of Functioning, Disability and Health) framework. The range of treatment approaches will be taught with an emphasis on evidence-based treatment approaches for the different types of SSD. Teaching and learning enhancement techniques will include case studies, videos and role play/simulations.

title: Craniofacial Anomalies
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: The course will cover craniofacial conditions, focusing on cleft lip and palate and craniofacial dysostosis.Students will learn how to undertaken a comprehensive perceptual assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal dysfunction using a standardized speech sampling protocol and listening protocol. Students will be exposed to treatment of cleft palate speech from early intervention to adulthood. The course will also cover instrumental assessment of cleft palate speech and velopharyngeal function. Students will also be exposed to primary and secondary (velopharyngeal) surgery in this client population and the inter-professional working paradigm within a cranofacial clinical service.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Identify and describe the roles of different professionals within a craniofacial team 2. Identify and describe perceptual and instrumental assessment methods in cleft lip and palate and velopharyngeal dysfunction 3. Identify and describe specific treatment approaches in CLP

title: Aural Rehabilitation and Audiology
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course will cover the fundamental audiological evaluations as well as a brief introduction on more advanced approaches. Students will learn about interpretation of audiological reports, major principles of speech perception assessment and various approaches of aural (re)habilitation for populations ranging from infants to older adults.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand the commonly used audiological tests and the various purposes that the tests may serve; 2. Describe the communication, language, speech and literacy characteristics of the individuals with hearing impairment; 3. Understand the critical concepts in speech perception assessments and aural (re)habilitation approaches across the age range.

title: Phonetics and Phonology for Speech-Language-Pathology
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: This course introduces students to a unified approach to language as a complex structure represented in the minds of its speakers. Empirical linguistic data will be drawn across languages to enable students to understand the intimate relation between language and the human mind. On the basis of this understanding, students are led to explore the core areas of linguistics. The exploration starts with natural language sound systems and phonological components of grammar. These will be explained with basic concepts and recent theoretical advances in linguistic studies alongside new findings in language acquisition. Students will learn to apply these concepts and ideas to tackle linguistic problems.

title: Syntax and Semantics for Speech-Language-Pathology
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: Taking a modular approach to the language system, this course examines the morphological, semantic and syntactic components of the grammar, as well as the interaction among them. The lectures are intended to provide students with a solid grounding in basic linguistic concepts, which will enable them to tackle linguistic problems, and formulate their own analyses to prepare them for further studies in the discipline. A wide range of data will be discussed to develop students’ sensitivity toward linguistic phenomena with systematic properties in form, meaning and structure.

title: Language Acquisition for Speech-Language-Pathology
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: The acquisition of first language by children has been considered a remarkable feat. How do children accomplish this feat so rapidly and effortlessly? What are the stages they go through in mastering the different aspects of language? What does the development of language in children tell us about the human language faculty? These questions will be examined in light of modern linguistic theory, and nativist and interactionist accounts will be compared. Topics in second language acquisition will also be covered. Questions such as how interlanguage grammars develop in adults and the role of the mother tongue in the construction of interlanguage grammar will be addressed.

title: Clinical Research
requirements: For students in MSc Speech-Language Pathology
description: The course introduces students on the necessary steps to formulate a research project in relation to a particular aspect of speech pathology. Each student will be guided by a supervisor throughout the processes from literature review, setting up research questions, data collection, applying appropriate research methodology and writing up results.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to be able to formulate an independent clinical Research on speech-language pathology.
